Expressions and Operators

An expression is a collection of operators and operands, or a literal value.

Normally, they can be written in a script as follows:

    expression;

When a semicolon is added after an expression like this, the expression is evaluated (= executed) on the spot, and the result of that expression is discarded.


Example:
    a = b;
    // Variable b is assigned to variable a by the operation of the = operator

    func();
    // func is called as a function by the operation of the ( ) operator, but the return value
    // is discarded

    1 + 3;
    // 1 and 3 are added by the operation of the + operator, but the result is discarded (in fact, this
    // expression is meaningless so it isn't even executed)

True and False

Several operators handle true or false (logical values). If the result of the evaluation is 0, it is false; if it is anything other than 0, it is true.
When a string is evaluated for truth, an empty string is false. In other cases, an attempt is made to convert it to a number; if successful, the resulting numerical value determines truth/falsehood, and if it fails, it is false.

Operators

The following explains operators in order from lowest priority to highest priority.

if Operator

The if operator if is an operator that evaluates the left side only if the result of evaluating the right side is true.

Example:
    a=b if b!=0; // If b is not 0, assign b to a

It is not possible to obtain a result from the operator itself.

Sequential Operator

The sequential operator , (comma) evaluates the left side and then evaluates the right side. It does nothing else. The overall result of the operator is the result of evaluating the right side. If multiple commas are written in succession, they are evaluated in order from left to right.

Example:
    c = (a=1, b=2); // a=1 and b=2 are evaluated, and 2 is assigned to c
    a=1, b=2, c=3; // Evaluated in the order a=1, b=2, c=3

Assignment Operators

The assignment operators include the following:

= <-> &= |= ^= -= += %= /= \= *= ||= &&= >>= <<= >>>=
Among these, the = operator is the simple assignment operator, which evaluates the right side and assigns the result to the left side. The overall value of the operator is the result of evaluating the right side.

Example:
    a = 0;  // Assign 0 to a
    a = b = c = 0; // Assign 0 in order to c, b, then a

The <-> operator performs a swap. First, the left side is evaluated, then the right side is evaluated. After that, the result of evaluating the right side is assigned to the left side, and the result of evaluating the left side is assigned to the right side. It is not possible to obtain a result from this operator.
At present, the left and right expressions are each evaluated twice: once to get the expression value and once to assign to the expression. Since this specification may change in the future, please avoid writing code that depends on the number of evaluations.

All other operators take the form of operator=. If written as A operator= B, it means A = A operator B. The value of the overall expression is the result of the calculation.

Conditional Operator

The conditional operator ? : is a ternary operator. Written in the format A ? B : C, it evaluates A; if true, it evaluates B and ignores C. If false, it evaluates C and ignores B. The value of the overall operator is the value of whichever side (B or C) was evaluated.

The conditional operator can be used as an l-value.

Example:
    a = b==0 ? c : b; // If b is 0, assign c to a; if b is not 0, assign b to a
    b==0 ? (a=c) : (a=b); // Same meaning as above
    (a ? b : c ) = d; // If a is true, assign d to b; if a is false, assign d to c (Example used as an l-value)

Logical OR Operator

The logical OR operator || first evaluates the left side; if true, it ignores the right side, and the overall result of the operator is true. If the result of evaluating the left side is false, it evaluates the right side, and the truth result of that evaluation becomes the overall result of the operator.

Logical AND Operator

The logical AND operator && first evaluates the left side; if false, it ignores the right side, and the overall result of the operator is false. If the result of evaluating the left side is true, it evaluates the right side, and that result becomes the overall result of the operator.

Bitwise OR Operator

The bitwise OR operator | performs a bitwise logical OR. It evaluates the left side and then the right side, treats the results as integers, and the bitwise OR of those integers becomes the overall value of the operator.

Bitwise XOR Operator

The bitwise XOR operator ^ performs a bitwise logical XOR. It evaluates the left side and then the right side, treats the results as integers, and the bitwise XOR of those integers becomes the overall value of the operator.

Bitwise AND Operator

The bitwise AND operator & performs a bitwise logical AND. It evaluates the left side and then the right side, treats the results as integers, and the bitwise AND of those integers becomes the overall value of the operator.

Equality Operators

== != === !== are types of equality operators.

== Operator
The == operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If both match, the overall operator is true; if they do not match, it is false. If the types differ as a result of evaluating both sides, they are converted appropriately before comparison. For example, -1 == '-1' is true.
!= Operator
The != operator is the logical inverse of the == operator.
=== Operator
The === operator is called the identity comparison operator; it is the same as the == operator, but no type conversion is performed, and it will not be true unless the types also match.
!== Operator
The !== operator is the logical inverse of the === operator.

Comparison Operators

< > <= >= are types of comparison operators.

< Operator
The < operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the left side is smaller than the result of evaluating the right side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.
> Operator
The > operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the right side is smaller than the result of evaluating the left side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.
<= Operator
The <= operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the left side is smaller than or equal to the result of evaluating the right side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.
>= Operator
The >= operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If the result of evaluating the right side is smaller than or equal to the result of evaluating the left side, it is true; otherwise, it is false.

If both items being compared are strings, the comparison is based on wide character code order (usually UNICODE).

Bit Shift Operators

>> << >>> are types of bit shift operators.

>> Operator
The >> operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. The left side is treated as an integer and shifted right by the number of bits specified by the right side (signed shift). The result is the value of the overall operator.
<< Operator
The << operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. The left side is treated as an integer and shifted left by the number of bits specified by the right side. The result is the value of the overall operator.
>>> Operator
The >>> operator is the same as the >> operator, but the result of evaluating the left side is treated as an unsigned integer.

Addition and Subtraction Operators

+ - are the addition and subtraction operators, respectively.

+ Operator
The + operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. If both results are numeric, numerical addition is performed, and it becomes the result of the overall operator. If either or both are strings, string addition (concatenation) is performed, and the overall operator becomes a string with the right result appended to the left result. Numbers are converted to strings, and object types are converted if they can be represented as strings.
- Operator
The - operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. Then, the right result is subtracted from the left result as numbers, and that becomes the overall value of the operator.

Multiplication, Division, and Remainder Operators

% / \ * are the remainder, division, integer division, and multiplication operators, respectively.

% Operator
The % operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. Then, the remainder of dividing the left side by the right side becomes the overall value of the operator. Both values are treated as integers.
/ Operator
The / operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. Then, the value of dividing the left side by the right side becomes the overall value of the operator. Values are treated as real numbers.
\ Operator
The \ operator performs division like the / operator, but the values are treated as integers.
* Operator
The * operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. Then, the value of the left side multiplied by the right side becomes the overall value of the operator. Values are treated as real numbers.

Common Unary Operators

All of the following are unary operators (with instanceof being an exception).

! Operator
The prefix ! operator is the logical NOT operator. The logical inverse of the right-side evaluation becomes the overall value of the operator.
~ Operator
The ~ operator is the bitwise NOT operator. The result of evaluating the right side is treated as an integer, and the bitwise NOT (1→0, 0→1) becomes the overall value of the operator.
-- Operator
The prefix -- operator is the prefix decrement operator. It subtracts 1 from the item on the right, and the value after subtraction becomes the overall value of the operator.
++ Operator
The prefix ++ operator is the prefix increment operator. It adds 1 to the item on the right, and the value after addition becomes the overall value of the operator.
new Operator
The new operator causes the function evaluation expression on the right to create an object instead of performing a simple function call.
invalidate Operator
The invalidate operator evaluates the item on the right and invalidates the resulting object. It does nothing if the item on the right is void, a string, a number, or an octet string. It also does nothing if the object is already invalidated. An exception occurs if null is specified.
isvalid Operator
The isvalid operator evaluates the item on the right or left side; it results in true if the object is valid and false if it is invalid. Placing the operator before or after the target has the same meaning. It always returns true if the target is void, a string, a number, or an octet string. An exception occurs if null is specified.
delete Operator
The delete operator deletes the member of the object or the local variable specified on the right. It returns true if deletion is successful and false if it fails.
typeof Operator
The typeof operator evaluates the item on the right and returns one of the following strings depending on its type: void:"void", integer:"Integer", real number:"Real", object:"Object", string:"String", octet string:"Octet". However, if an object member is specified and that member does not exist, it results in "undefined".
# Operator
The # operator evaluates the item on the right and takes the character code of the first character of the string as the overall value of the operator.
$ Operator
The $ operator evaluates the item on the right, treats the result as a character code, and takes the single character it represents as the overall value of the operator.
+ Operator
The unary + operator evaluates the item on the right. It does nothing if the right side is a real number or integer. Otherwise, it attempts to convert it to a real number or integer, and the result becomes the overall result of the operator. When attempting to convert a string to a number, it will result in 0 if conversion fails, without generating an exception. If it is a real number representation including a decimal point, it is converted to a real number; otherwise, it is converted to an integer. If the string starts with 0x, 0b, or 0, it is interpreted as hexadecimal, binary, or octal, respectively.
- Operator
The unary - operator evaluates the item on the left, treats the result as a number, and takes its negative as the overall result of the operator.
& Operator
The unary & operator changes access to an object member written on the right to access the property object itself, without going through the property handler. For example, in propobj = &obj.prop;, the property handler for obj's member property prop is not activated, and a reference to the property object itself of member property prop is assigned to propobj. Behavior is undefined if the right side is not an access to a property.
* Operator
The unary * operator activates the property handler of the object written on the right. The right side must be an expression representing a property object. For example, *propobj = 1; calls the setter handler of the property object propobj and assigns 1.
instanceof Operator
The instanceof operator evaluates the left side and then the right side. The right side should be a class name or a string representing one; if the item on the left is an instance of that class, it is true; otherwise, it is false.

Function Calls, Brackets, Post-increment/decrement, etc.

( ) Operator
The ( ) operator changes the priority of operations or performs a function call.
[ ] Operator
The [ ] operator is the indirect member selection operator. When written as A [ B ], A is evaluated first, then B. B is treated as a string to find that member name in A, and the overall operator becomes an access to that member. When used as an l-value, it also includes the action of creating member B within the object if it does not exist.
. Operator
The . operator is the direct member selection operator. When written as A.B, A is evaluated. B is searched for in A, and the overall operator becomes an access to that member. When used as an l-value, it also includes the action of creating member B within the object if it does not exist.
If the left side of the . operator is omitted, it refers to a member within the global object if outside a with statement, or a member of the object specified by with if inside a with statement.
++ Operator
The postfix ++ operator is the postfix increment operator. It adds 1 to the item on the left, and the overall operator results in the value of the left item before the addition.
-- Operator
The postfix -- operator is the postfix decrement operator. It subtracts 1 from the item on the left, and the overall operator results in the value of the left item before the subtraction.
! Operator
The postfix ! operator is the expression evaluation operator. It treats the result of evaluating the item on the left as a string and interprets it as an expression string. The result is the result of interpreting and evaluating that expression string. The expression operates on the this context (the this at the position where this operator is used).
incontextof Operator
The incontextof operator evaluates the left side first, then the right side. Treating the result of evaluating the left side as an object, the overall result of the operation is that object with its context part replaced by the result of evaluating the right side.
int Operator
The int operator evaluates the item on the right, and the result of the overall operator is that value converted to an integer type. It can also be written like a C-style cast: (int).
real Operator
The real operator evaluates the item on the right, and the result of the overall operator is that value converted to a real number type. It can also be written like a C-style cast: (real).
string Operator
The string operator evaluates the item on the right, and the result of the overall operator is that value converted to a string type. It can also be written like a C-style cast: (string).
